Graphical abstract This review provides a critical survey with all the essential information on the non-metal doping methods for improving TiO2 photocatalysts for solar-driven PC/PEC water splitting H2 generation. Photocatalytic (PC) / Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting under solar light irradiation is considered as a prospective technique to support the sustainable and renewable H2 economy and to reach the ultime goal of carbon neutral. TiO2 based photocatalysts with high chemical stability and excellent photocatalytic properties have great potential for solar-to-H2 conversion. To conquer the challenges of the large band-gap and rapid recombination of photo generated electron-holepairs in TiO2, non-metal doping turns out to be economic, facile, and effective on boosting the visible light activity. The localized defect states such as oxygen vacancy and Ti3+ generated by non-metal doping are located in the band-gap of TiO2, which result in the reduction of band-gap, thus a red-shift of the absorption edge. The hetero doping atoms such as B3+, I7+, S4+/S6+, P5+ can also act as electron donors or trap sites which facilitate the charge carrier separation and suppress the recombination of electron-hole pairs. In this comprehensive review, we present the most recent advances on non-metal doped TiO2 photocatalysts in terms of fundamental aspects, origin of visible light activity and the PC / PEC behaviours for water splitting. In particular, the characteristics of different non-metal elements (N, C, B, S, P, Halogens) as dopants are discussed in details focusing on the synthesis approaches, characterization as well as the efficiency of PC and PEC water splitting. The present review aims at guiding the readers who want quick access to helpful information about how to efficiently improve the performance of photocatalysts by simple doping strategies and could stimulate new intuitive into the new doping strategies. Keywords Photocatalytic/Photoelectrochemical water splitting Titania Non-metal doping Visible light photocatalysis 1 Introduction The actual major energy sources still root in non-renewable fossil fuels, which are petroleum, coal, betumes, natural gas, shale oil, etc. This unsustainable energy consumption also results in environmental deterioration such as air and water pollution and global warming. In order to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, carbon neutrality by mid-21st century is essential. Alternative clean and renewable energy sources are urgently needed [1–4]. Solar energy is abundantly available and clean, it has become the key to alleviate the energy crisis and environmental issues among all renewable energy resources (biomass, wind, geothermal, marine, etc.) [4,5]. On the other hand, H2 is one of the most promising energy carriers as the most abundant element in earth. Due to its cleanliness, and high energy efficiency, H2 plays a crucial role in driving modern energy system for the future sustainable development. Thus, converting solar energy into usable and storable form particularly like H2 in a both economically and environmentally friendly way is highly desirable [6–8]. Since Honda and Fujishima first used titania photoanodes for decomposing water into H2 and O2 in 1972, PC / PEC water splitting using semiconducting materials as photocatalysts / photoelectrodes has long been studied as the potential route for H2 production using solar light [9–12]. In the past decades, a large series of metal oxides and new types of semiconducting materials have been developed as photocatalysts or photoelectrodes to increase the efficiency of PC / PEC water splitting [13–18]. Considering the efficiency and stability in the liquid media, TiO2 is still the most attractive and investigated photocatalyst. It is well-known that TiO2 has strong photocatalytic activity, superior chemical stability, high resistant against corrosion in the aqueous media, as well as nontoxicity and low cost [19–23]. For evaluating the efficiency of photocatalytic water splitting of TiO2, several criteria such as Solar To H2 (STH) efficiency, Incident Photon-to-Current Efficiency (IPCE) and Absorbed Photon-to-Current Efficiency (APCE) have often been used. The most acceptable benchmark is the STH efficiency. Although the conversion efficiency of TiO2 has successfully been improved during these last years, the STH efficiency of most TiO2 based materials is around 1%–2%, which remains at a very low level and far from the industrial application [24,25]. The first reason is due to the large band-gap of TiO2, it only absorbs ultraviolet light (about 3%–5% of total solar light), and the utilization of solar light is vastly restricted. On the other hand, pure TiO2 photocatalyst suffers from the fast recombination of photo-excited electron-hole pairs, which decreases the efficiency of photo-energy conversion [26–29]. Considerable efforts have been made to reduce the band-gap of TiO2 to extend the light absorption to visible region by a series of approaches, such as coupling with narrow-band-gap materials, dye sensitization, and surface plasmonic treatment. In fact, one of the most developed modification strategies for enhancing the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 employs metals especially noble metals, such as Ru, Rh, Au, Pd and Pt etc. With the assistance of these noble metals, the performance of TiO2 in photocatalysis for H2 or O2 evolution is significantly improved owing to the lowered activation energy and increased electron donor concentration [30–38]. Unfortunately, all metal-compounded TiO2 materials have problems on thermal stability and the increased recombination centres of the charge carriers [39,40]. The lifetime of photo-generated charge carriers is an important issue determining the STH efficiently [26,40–43]. Furthermore, the above-mentioned noble metals are expensive and will cause the secondary water contamination. Thus, on account of effectively sustainable development of H2 production in industry, the utilization of noble metals is not a favourable option [26,44,45]. The research attention has therefore been shifted to non-metal doping for tuning the electronic, chemical, and photocatalytic properties of TiO2. Sato et al. initially reported the photocatalytic activity of nitrogen doped TiO2 with the absorption band around 450 nm, the substitutional doping of nitrogen was believed to result in the band-gap narrowing of TiO2 [46]. Then, Asahi et al. also revealed visible light absorption (>460 nm) and enhanced photocatalytic activity of nitrogen doped TiO2 in the form of TiO2- x [47]. Afterwards, other non-metal (such as C, S, B, P, Halogens) doped TiO2 have also been found to be photoactive under visible light [48–59]. Non-metal doping can alter the electronic structure of TiO2 by introducing localized states in the band-gap and lead to a reconstructive of the surface structure of TiO2, facilitating the charge transfer [60–64]. For example, Wu et al. synthesized carbon-doped TiO2 nanotubes via Chemical Vapor Deposition with estimated band-gap of around 2.72 eV and 150 times higher photocurrent compared to that of pristine TiO2 under visible light irradiation. The enhanced photo-response was ascribed to the modified electronic properties induced by the carbon insertion in the TiO2 crystal lattice [65]. Yang et al. modified rutile TiO2 by the sulphur doping and the unique sulphide surface (TiO2- x : S) resulted in enhanced visible-light absorption, efficient charge transfer and 30-fold improvement on photocatalytic activity for water splitting over the pure TiO2 [66]. There are several reviews on the attainment and progress on TiO2 photocatalysis. Most of them focus on the application of TiO2 for the environmental remediation especially for the water / air purification [50,67–80]. Others summarized photocatalytic H2 production including PEC water splitting focusing on metal doped, compounded TiO2 [8,26,41,43,81,82] or heterostructured TiO2 [83–85]. A few perceptive reviews discussed about non-metal doped TiO2 from the theoretical aspect [62,67,86]. Up to now, the comprehensive review on non-metal doped TiO2 for PC / PEC water splitting is still missing. Thus, we felt that a comprehensive review outlining the most recent advances in non-metal doped photocatalysts (for PC) / electrodes (for PEC) would be beneficial to this evolving field of important current interest. In this review, the specific band-gap tuning and the possible origin of visible light activity of non-metal doped TiO2 photocatalysts for PC and PEC water splitting will be discussed in details. Different doping pathways and the characterization techniques are summarized with a particular attention. We intend to review the most recent advancements including the basic concepts, the developed mechanisms and new breakthroughs on non-metal doped TiO2 for both PC and PEC water splitting. After the introduction, the basic principles of PC / PEC water splitting will be presented in Section 2. Different non-metal doping strategies to improve PC / PEC efficiency are presented in Section 3. In the Section 4, a series of techniques currently used for non-metal doping characterization are described to get precious information on doping form, doping concentrations and doping effect on electronic, optical and structural properties of semiconducting materials. The correlation between doping methods and resultant PC / PEC water splitting activities is deeply discussed in Section 5. The conclusion and perspective of non metal doping are given at the end of this review. This review provides a unique comprehensive and critical survey with all the essential information on the non-metal doping methods, the characterization techniques and the effect of each non-metal doping element and methods on the PC / PEC water splitting improvement efficiency. We hope that the present review by careful selection of representative examples will be helpful for those entering the field and for those in the field who want quick access to all the helpful information about the non-metal doping methods for improving their photocatalysts for PC / PEC water splitting. 2 Basic principles of PC / PEC water splitting 2.1 PC water splitting Photocatalytic water splitting is used to decompose water into its constituent, H2 and O2 using a photocatalyst irradiated by natural or simulated sunlight as shown in Fig. 1 . During this process, the photon energy is absorbed and converted into chemical energy, which is very similar to the activity occurring in the photosynthesis of green plants. Therefore, photocatalytic water splitting is considered as an artificial photosynthesis for H2 production. In the photocatalytic system, the water splitting for H2 production over semiconductor photocatalyst could be separated into following processes: (i) Photoexcitation of charges When the semiconducting photocatalysts are irradiated by sunlight, electron-hole pairs are generated on the surface of a photocatalyst, for example, TiO2. The reaction can be expressed in Eq. (1), as shown in Fig. 2 . (1) T i O 2 + h ν → e - + h + (ii) Charge recombination and separation strategies The electrons in the Conduction Band Minimum (CBM) of TiO2 largely recombine with the holes in Valence Band Maximum (VBM) of TiO2 resulting in low efficiency of charge transfer. Thus, electron acceptors and donors such as cocatalysts and sacrificial reagent are often employed to suppress the recombination of electron / hole pairs and the reverse reaction of H2 and O2 into water [89]. Non-metal doping in TiO2 can also help to improve the charge separation by band gap engineering of TiO2 [67,86]. (iii) Charges transfer and photocatalytic reactions The successfully separated electrons and holes would be transferred to the surface of TiO2 and react with protons (H+) to produce H2 and with H2O to generate O2, respectively. (Fig. 2 (2) and (3)). The reduction (Eq. (2)) and oxidation (Eq. (3)) reactions are the basic principles for photocatalytic water splitting. (2) R e d u c t i o n : 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 (3) O x i d a t i o n : H 2 O + h + → 2 H + + 1 2 O 2 (4) O v e r a l l r e a c t i o n : H 2 O → H 2 + 1 2 O 2 (iv) The overall water splitting The overall water splitting reaction (Eq. (4)) is an uphill reaction which involves positive change in Gibbs free energy (ΔG o) of 237 kJ/mol (1.23 eV). To facilitate the oxidation–reduction reactions, the conduction band (CB) of the photocatalyst must be lower than the H+/H2 reduction potential (0 V vs. NHE) and the valence band (VB) must be higher than the H2O/O2 oxidation potential (+1.23 V vs. NHE) [87]. The higher the VB energy position of the semiconductors, the lower the oxidizing power in water splitting reactions. The VBM of TiO2 is mainly composed of oxygen 2p orbitals with a potential of approximately 3 V vs. NHE. While the CBM is derived from titanium 3d orbitals and is more negative than 0 V vs. NHE [40,88]. Therefore, the oxidation–reduction potentials (OPR) of H+/H2 and H2O/O2 are located between the CBM and the VBM of TiO2. 2.2 PEC water splitting The PEC water splitting system often employs three type cells which use n-type semiconductor as photoanode, p-type semiconductor as photocathode and a tandem system including n-type photoanode and p-type photocathode [422]. The photogenerated electrons on the n-type photoanodes transfer to counter electrode (cathode) producing an anodic photocurrent and reducing the H+ into H2 at the cathode. On the contrary, the photogenerated holes on the p-type photocathode transfer to counter electrode (anode) producing a cathodic photocurrent and oxidizing water into O2 and H+ [423,424]. In the tandem cell, both n-type photoanode and p-type photocathode absorb light energy oxidizing water into O2 and reducing H+ into H2, respectively [425]. TiO2 is a typical n-type semiconductor which is usually employed as photoanode in an n-type PEC cell as shown in Fig. 3 . When the n-type TiO2 works as the photoanode, the holes are accumulated at the interface between TiO2 and the electrolyte solution and participate in the oxygen-evolution half-reaction (OER). Meanwhile the electrons are transferred to the counter electrode, for example the most widely used platinum electrode, through the conductive electrolyte medium and involved subsequently in the H2-evolution half-reaction (HER). Under the acid electrolyte condition in the PEC cell, the protons and H2O molecules adsorbed on electrodes will be reduced at cathode and oxidized at anode by electrons and holes, respectively, as expressed in Eq. (2) and Eq. (3). In high pH (≥7) electrolyte solution (alkaline or neutral media), the two half reactions can be given in Eq. (5) and Eq. (6). (5) R e d u c t i o n a t c a t h o d e : 2 H 2 O + 2 e - → H 2 + 2 O H - (6) O x i d a t i o n a t a n o d e : 2 O H - + 2 h + → 1 2 O 2 + H 2 O Generally, the overall chemical reaction of PEC water splitting is made up of two independent half-reactions, which respond to the interfacial potential difference at the corresponding electrodes and consequently change the chemical composition of the PEC system [90]. Since the potentials of both working electrode and counter electrode change with the overall reaction of water splitting, the reference electrode with substantially stable composition is needed to standardize the potential of the whole system. The most acceptable reference electrodes considered as standard for zero potential are as follows: NHE (Normal Hydrogen Electrode): potential of a platinum electrode in 1 M acid solution at 25 ○C. SHE (Standard Hydrogen Electrode): potential of a platinum electrode in a theoretical ideal solution (the current standard for zero potential for all temperatures). RHE (Reversible Hydrogen Electrode): a practical hydrogen electrode whose potential depends on the pH of the solution at 25 ○C. In practical PEC measurements, hydrogen electrodes are not convenient to quote from an experimental standpoint. The common reference electrodes are the saturated calomel electrode (SCE), Hg/Hg2Cl2/KCl (saturated in water) with potential of 0.244 V vs. RHE (pH = 0) and the silver-silver chloride electrode, Ag/AgCl/KCl (saturated in water) with a potential of 0.198 V vs. RHE (pH = 0). An external voltage is applied between working electrode based on semiconducting materials and the reference electrode to equilibrate the Fermi level of the semiconductor and the work function of the metal counter electrode. By driving the electrode to more negative potentials, the energy of the electrons is raised and reaches a level high enough to transfer into vacant electronic states on species in the electrolyte. When a flow of electrons from electrode to solution, a reduction current occurs. In reverse, the energy of the electrons is lowered after imposing a more positive potential, and electrons in the electrolyte will be in favour of a certain energy on the electrode and will transfer there. The flow of electrons from solution to electrode is an oxidation current. In this case, the transfer of the electrons within the working electrode can be controlled by manipulating the potential of the working electrode with respect to the reference. And electrons transfer to the counter electrode and charges separation as well as water splitting reactions can be assured at the same time. 2.3 Efficiency of PC / PEC water splitting The solar to H2 conversion efficiency (STH) is generally used to describe the H2 production efficiency of PC water splitting. STH efficiency is the ratio of the “H2-energy output” to the “solar energy input” at 25 ○C, which can be described in Eq. (7) [91]. (7) S T H = m m o l H 2 / s ∗ ( 237 k J / m o l ) P t o t a l m W / c m 2 ∗ A r e a ( c m 2 ) A M 1.5 G Where P total represents the power density (mW/cm2) of incident simulated sunlight (AM1.5G). For PEC water splitting, the numerator is the product of photocurrent density (j sc) at zero bias (short-circuit photocurrent), the thermodynamic voltage required for water splitting (1.23 V), and the faradic efficiency (η F), as expressed in Eq.(8). (8) S T H = j S C m A / c m 2 ∗ 1 . 23 V ∗ η F P t o t a l m W / c m 2 A M 1.5 G To know the contribution of light of different wavelengths region to STH efficiency, the NREL (National Renewable Energy Laboratory) standard spectrum of AM1.5G as solar spectrum is displayed in Fig. 4 . With a quantum efficiency (QE) of 100%, the entire UV photons account for a maximum theoretical STH efficiency of only 3.3%, light ≤600 nm (2.07 eV) results in 17.8%. While up to 1000 nm (1.23 eV), the STH efficiency can be calculated to be ~48% (using a single semiconductor). The fact clearly reveals that the visible light makes the major contribution to STH efficiency indicating the significance of improving the visible-light activity of photocatalysts. The IPCE describes the ratio of photocurrent collected to incident photon flux. The IPCE is one of the most important diagnostic values obtained from a chronoamperometry (potentiostatic) measurement. The STH efficiency can be ideally estimated from the integration of the IPCE data over the solar spectrum. The IPCE can be given as a function of wavelength (λ) as shown in Eq. (9). (9) I P C E λ = e l e c t r o n s / c m 2 / s p h o t o n s / c m 2 / s = j p h m A / c m 2 ∗ 1239 . 8 ( V ∗ n m ) P m o n o m W / c m 2 ∗ λ ( n m ) where 1239.8 V * nm is the product of h (Planck’s constant) and c (the speed of light), and the P mono is the calibrated illumination power intensity of the monochromatic light. Both PC and PEC water splitting employing photoactive semiconductors are two main approaches in converting solar energy into chemical energy form. The PC system mainly uses powder-based catalysts while PEC system utilizes thin film-based electrodes fabricated with catalytic materials. A comparison of the PC and PEC systems is summarized in Table 1 . Until now, the STH of TiO2 remains at a relatively low scale (<1%) due to the wide band-gap of TiO2 and the rapid recombination of electron / hole pairs. [93] 3 Synthetic strategies for non-metal doped TiO2 The PC activity of TiO2 is closely related to the crystalline phase, morphology, specific surface area, doping amount and forms, which are dependent on the preparation methods. Extensive work about synthesis of non-metal doped TiO2 have been reported. The main doping strategies are summarized providing a comprehensive understanding of non-metal doping process in TiO2. The innovations on synthesis protocols and morphologies modulation are illustrated. 3.1 Wet-chemical preparations The wet-chemical fabrications including sol–gel process method, hydrothermal treatment, and microwave-assisted method are widely explored to prepare various non-metal (N, C, S, B, P and Halogens) doped TiO2. The benefits of these three methods are mainly derived from the easy manoeuvrability and controllability in the doping level and particle sizes by simple variations of the experimental conditions, such as hydrolysis rate, solution pH value and solvent systems [94–96]. These three methods have some similarities as shown in Fig. 5 . The sol–gel method of doping TiO2 is normally operated at ambient temperature and pressure while the hydrothermal way is usually carried out in an autoclave keeping at a specific temperature with autogenous pressure. The microwave-assisted method is often combined with the sol–gel or hydrothermal methods using a microwave reactor to speed up the formation of the products during the doping process. The solution A is formed by titanium precursors such as titanium isopropoxide (TIP) [97], tetrabutylorthotitanate (TBOT) [98], and titanium tetrachloride [99] in their solvent. As summarized in Table 2 , amine [100,101], ammonia [102,103] and urea [104–106] [434] are commonly used as precursors for nitrogen doping. For carbon doping, there are abundant organic compounds serving as the carbon sources such as methanol [107], cellulose [108,109], glucose [110–113] and chitosan, etc. The sulfuric acid or sulphate precursors, thiourea have been applied as sulphur sources [114–116]. The B and P sources are normally provided by boric acid [117–119] and phosphorous acid [120–122] or phosphate [120,121], respectively. The researches on halogen elements doping other than F in TiO2 are relatively rare. The fluorine doping typically uses ammonium fluoride [123,124], chlorine dopant usually comes from the residuals from chloroform [125] and the iodine doping mostly employs iodic acid [126,127]. The wet chemical methods including sol–gel, hydrothermal, and microwave reactions are excellent processes for synthesis low-demensional TiO2 nanocarystals such as nanoparticles [139–143], tubular structure [129,132,139] with large specific surface area, homogeneous doping sites, and the followed enhanced PC activity [129,132,139–143]. In addition, other wet-chemical methods such as hydrothermal assisted self-assembly of nanoparticles [166,426,427] and the inorganic self-template co-precipitation method[428,429] are known as superior processes for construction core–shell, mesoporous, and hierarchical meso-/microporous structured TiO2. 3.2 One-step thermal treatment The one-step thermal treatment involves three specific approaches which are presented as follows: a. Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) of TiO2 in gas atmospheres with doping species [66,177-185]. b. Physical Deposition (PD) such as sputtering and pulsed laser deposition of TiO2 or Ti related targets with mixture of carrier gas and doping species as the reactive gas [47,186–192]. c. Incomplete oxidizing compounds of TiO2. Typically, Ti and doping elements were bestrewed on combustion boat and loaded into a muffle furnace, then were rapidly heated in the air / inertia gas atmospheres, for the oxidation of Ti into Target-doping-emements-TiO2 [192–199]. Compared to the hydrothermal process, one-step thermal treatment is simple, versatile, scalable, and fast. Specially, the first and second approaches are frequently used for non-metal doped TiO2 preparation, especially for thin films with high purity and conformal morphology [188,200–203]. Considering the similarity on gas phase doping in TiO2 by thermal treatment and physical deposition, the overview of non-metal doping by CVD and PD approaches is given in Table 3 . The third approach is facile and normally used for N, C and S doping by incomplete oxidation of inorganic compounds such as TiN [193,195], TiC [192,197] and TiS2 [63,194]. However, the doping concentration is hard to control even by managing the calcination conditions such as temperature, duration, gas flow, ramping rate, and cooling rate. Thus, the improvement on vis-photoactivity of the doped TiO2 by such approach is very limited. 3.3 Anodization Table 4 presents a list of synthesis of non-metal doped TiO2 made by anodization. The electrochemical anodization is widely employed to synthesis TiO2 nanotubes using a metallic titanium substrate in an F- containing electrolyte. The Ti was oxide into Ti4+ and the oxide layers were gradually formed on the substrate surface. Due to the chemical dissolution TiO2 layer in the F- environment, the tubular structure on the metal substrate was synthesized [256,436,437]. This type of self-aligned oxide nanotube layers has attracted considerable interest over the past 20 years [436] [421]. By adding non-metal precursors in the electrolytes, the one-step non-metal-doped TiO2 nanotubes with a unique structure, high specific area, and high absorption ability can be achieved [256–258] . 3.4 Physical methods The ions implantation and plasma treatment are two physical methods often used for doping thin films photocatalysts (Table 5 ). In principle, all species including H2 can be incorporated into TiO2 by ion implantation technique. It seems that the dopant content and location can be adjusted by the parameters of implanter including the fluence and the energy. The defects in TiO2 produced by ion bombardment can be annealed out afterwards. However, the ion scattering still results in inhomogeneous dopant distribution in the presupposed depth. Even with high-energy accelerators (operating at 50–1000 keV), the implantation depth is limited to micrometres. Moreover, the whole set of ion implanter is complicated, thus the doping by ion implantation stays at the preliminarily stage. Up to present, the plasma modification way is only applied for the nitrogen doping in TiO2 by using N2 or NH3 as the N sources [261,262]. The interstitial doping is favoured by N2-plasma treatment whereas substitutional N doping with oxygen vacancies is preferred by reductive NH3-plasma treatment. N-plasma surface modification has effectively enhanced the PC activity of TiO2 without any damage on its structure [261,263]. 4 Characterization techniques for non-metal doping To investigate the doping form and the concentration of non-metal in TiO2 and to deeply understand the doping effect on the PC and PEC property of TiO2, several characterization techniques are particularly applicable for non-metal dopants. Here we give a review on a series of very lately used characterization techniques for non-metal doped photocatalysts. By careful selection of examples, we show essential information drawn from each technique and the interpretation of obtained results and their correlation with PC properties. This part of presentation can help researchers of the field to choose right techniques to get desired information. 4.1 UV–Visible absorption / diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–VIS/DRS) The colour change of TiO2 materials after doping with non-metal elements observed by human naked eyes is a first and direct indication of their ability to absorb light in the visible region. For example, the macroscopic colour of TiO2 (Fig. 6 a) changes from white to yellow, black, brown by doping with N, C, P, as shown in Fig. 6(b), (c) and (d), respectively. The change of colour also depends on the doping concentration as seen in Fig. 6(e). The colour of TiO2 has become brown, grey, and green with increasing the amount of doped Boron from 2 to 10 wt%. For specific determination of the changes in the optical property of TiO2, the UV–VIS and DRS are applied. Normally, the former one is used for samples in forms of solutions/suspensions or thin films, whereas the latter one is used for solid samples. After the doping, the light absorption of TiO2 especially in visible region can significantly be enhanced leading to the improved photoactivity. As shown in Fig. 6(f), the intensity of visible-light absorption between 400 and 780 nm (the photoenergy between 3.1 eV and 1.59 eV) increases with boron doping in TiO2. In addition, the absorption edge of boron doped TiO2 is red shifted compared to that of pure TiO2 indicating the interactions between boron dopant and TiO2. Moreover, DSR provide information about the electronic behaviours in a solid. [273] Thus, the induced changes in electronic band structure of TiO2 can potentially be estimated from the obtained DSR. The band-gap energy (E g) of TiO2 can be calculated according to Kubelka-Monk function, which is modified into following equation Eq. (10) [273]: (10) α ( h ν ) ≈ A ( h ν - E g ) n where α is the extinction coefficient, which is proportional to Absorbance or F(R). And h is the Planck’s constant (J. s), ν is the light frequency (s−1), A is the absorption constant. The n equals to 2 or ½ corresponding to indirect allowed transition and direct allowed transition in TiO2, respectively. The value of hν can be expressed as follow equation Eq. (11), (11) h ν = h c λ ≈ 1240 λ e V Thus, the original UV–VIS spectrum (Absorbance or F(R) versus λ) is transformed into plot with (αhν)1/2 or (αhν)2 versus hν. The E g value can be calculated by extrapolating the tangent line to α = 0. Fig. 6(f-h) presents the diffuse absorption spectra of P-RP (Pure red phosphorus), P-TiO2 (Pure TiO2) and RP-TiO2-12 h (Red phosphorus milled with TiO2 for 12 h). The transformed plots with (αhν)1/2 vs. hν are shown in Fig. 6(g and h), the band-gap energies are found to be 3.2 eV (387 nm) for P-TiO2 and 2.5 eV (496 nm) for RP-TiO2-12 h. The significant band-gap narrowing is attributed to phosphorus doping into the TiO2 lattice. Besides, an additional lower band-gap of 1.5 eV is generated by the conduction band tail states of phosphorus that extends below the CBM. The transformed DSR of sulphur doped TiO2 is shown in Fig. 6(i), the plot fitted from the double Boltzmann function can be divided into two sloping curves resulting in two tangents. Two energy values have been calculated to be 2.27 eV (546 nm) and 3.21 eV (386 nm) for the region of S doping (E g1) and for the anatase TiO2 (E g2) respectively. The result of UV–VIS spectra suggests that TiO2 is successfully doped by S. The generation of a new mid-gap level above the valence band of TiO2 is thus proposed. Even though the UV–VIS is the mostly employed technique describing the modification in electronic structures of doped TiO2, there exist disagreements on the evaluation of E g of doped TiO2 because it is difficult to separate the Kubelka-Monk spectrum derived from the original UV–VIS spectra into individual spectra of pure TiO2 and doped TiO2 [274]. In addition, the composite of dopant materials and TiO2 is often formed during the preparation of doped TiO2. With the interference of composite on the UV–VIS spectra of TiO2, the accuracy of Kubelka-Monk function is not sufficient to calculate the exact E g of doped TiO2. UV–VIS can be assisted with other methods to estimate the band-gap of non-metal doped TiO2 such as Tauc plotting of incident photon conversion efficiency (IPCE) spectra and theoretical calculation of band structure derived from density functional theory (DFT) [419] [451]. The former one is based on the assumption that amount of absorbed photons which refers to the absorption efficiency is proportional to the photocurrent density. Since the IPCE spectra do not take the recombined photogenerated electron / hole pairs into account, the band-gap derived from these spectra is larger than the actual band-gap of TiO2. Comparing to experimental characterization, the theoretical calculation of electronic structure such as DFT could be more feasible avoiding practical errors even there exists deviation between calculated and experimental band-gap [452,453]. Therefore, the optical absorption spectra (UV–VIS / DSR) combined with IPCE spectra and the computation can be very useful to investigate the doping effect on the band structure and the followed PC property of TiO2. 4.2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS is a widely used and essential technique for characterization of surface chemical composition and states of solid materials. The incorporation of various non-metal dopants into TiO2 has been investigated by XPS. For example, in N doped TiO2, the substitutional nitrogen doping in the form of TiN gives a peak of the N 1s core level at approximately 396–398 eV [275]. The peaks at Binding Energy (BE) between 398–402 eV suggest the existence of N-Ti-O or O-Ti-N bond [276]. N 1s peaks on N-TiO2 observed at higher BEs (404–408 eV) can be ascribed to chemisorbed N2, NO or NO2 type species [277]. The XPS spectra of TiO2 and N-TiO2 are shown in Fig. 7 (a), the peak of Ti 2p3/2 is observed at 459.3 and 458.5 eV for TiO2 and N-TiO2 respectively. Lower BE of Ti 2p in N-TiO2 implies the electronic interaction of Ti with the dopant. The N 1s core level from N-TiO2 appearing at 398.2 eV can be attributed to the anionic N- in O-Ti-N linkages. The O 1s peaks in two samples are both at approximately 530 eV indicating no significant interaction between N and O. All the information suggest a substitutional N doping in TiO2. The XPS provides the information not only about the doping type but also the total density of states (DOS) of the Valence Band (VB) [278,279]. Fig. 7(b) shows the XPS spectra of the C, S, and N doped TiO2. Additional diffusive electronic states above the VB edge of pure TiO2 are brought by the C 2p, S 3p, and N 2p orbitals. The transitions between these dopant-induced levels and Ti 3d orbitals can explain the observed visible-light absorptions of non-metal doped TiO2. It is worth noting that the XPS peaks of non-metal doped TiO2 are still under debate with controversial hypotheses in the literature. The observations in XPS spectra of TiO2 also vary with different preparation methods. 4.3 Electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) EPR, also known as electron spin resonance spectroscopy (ESR), is a technique for detecting species with unpaired electrons, such as free radicals, transition metal ions, and defects in materials in the presence of an externally applied static magnetic field [282]. EPR can provide the essential information of the local structure, paramagnetic centres such as Ti3+ and oxygen vacancy in TiO2. Due to its unique sensibility for detecting species at very low concentration, this technique can directly reveal the fate of valence holes and the conduction electrons as well as their interfacial photoreaction in TiO2. EPR has become a key method to characterize non-metal doped TiO2 for visible-light induced photocatalysis [122,153,280,283,284]. EPR active signals are from Ti3+ and ionized oxygen vacancy in TiO2 (VO). In an external magnetic field B, the Landé g factor which is a multiplicative term appearing in the expression for the energy levels of an atom (named after Alfred Landé) can be evaluated through a well-known relation, (12) g = h ν u B B where ν is the applied microwave frequency (9451 MHz) and u B is the Bohr magneton. Generally, a resonant value at g > 2.0 is due to the VO, while signal at g < 2.0 is from Ti3+ defects [285]. Fig. 8 (a) shows the EPR measurement of pure TiO2 and N doped TiO2 samples at room temperature. A strong EPR signal observed at g = 2.003 only in N/TiO2 is characteristic feature of O· - radicals trapped in oxygen vacancy sites which are known as single-electron-trapped oxygen vacancies (SETOV). No obvious resonance from Ti3+ is observed in both pure and doped samples. The intensity of EPR signal is proportional to the concentration of paramagnetic species. For example, the amount of oxygen vacancies (SETOV) observed in P0.1-TiO2 (10 wt% phosphorus doped TiO2) is approximately 6 times greater than that in P0.01-TiO2 (1 wt% phosphorus doped TiO2) as shown in Fig. 8(b). The photo-response of these paramagnetic centres was also investigated in carbon doped TiO2. As shown in Fig. 8(c), the observed signals in the EPR spectrum are attributed to the oxygen related centres (g > 2.0) and trapped electrons at Ti3+ sites in anatase (g < 2.0). The visible light illumination significantly enhances the EPR intensity at the g = 2.003 spectral region. Because of the anion radicals like CO− doping in TiO2 lattice, the amount of oxygen vacancies is increased. As shown in the inset of Fig. 8(c), the localized C 2p states and C-O states account for the emergence of the observed EPR signals at g = 2.0034 and 2.0023 which are also enhanced by the visible light illumination. The broad signal emerged at the g = 1.930 was attributed to the wide distribution of Ti3+ surface states below the CB of TiO2 by the sub-band gap illumination of the LED source. The paramagnetic characteristics obtained from the EPR measurement indicate that these various defect states in the C-doped TiO2 are responsible for the visible light absorption. In general, non-metal doped TiO2 have defects including vacancies, interstitials and substitutional dopants with unpaired electrons or spins which are detectable and monitored by EPR spectrometers. EPR characterization provides useful information about defect types even at ultra-low concentration induced by non-metal dopants and changes of charge state before and after an irradiation. Thus, the EPR studies can help to track detailed species derived from doping and the origin of visible light response. 4.4 Photoluminescence spectroscopy (PL) The PL is the light emission resulting from the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs which is crucial in photocatalysis. The PL spectra are widely used for investigating the efficiency of charge carriers trapping, migration and transfer. Fig. 9 shows the observed PL spectra of pure TiO2 and N, S, Ag doped TiO2. A broad peak at around 580 nm in the PL spectra is attributed to the fluorescence emission from the recombination of the photoexcited electrons in the CB and holes in the VB. The PL intensity in the spectra of pure TiO2 is high due to the massive recombination of photoinduced charge carriers. While the PL intensity decreases with N and S co-doping in TiO2 indicating the suppressed charge recombination. The decreased PL intensity can thus confirm the enhanced electron / hole separation efficiency in TiO2 by N and S co-doping. In general, the PL spectra direct provide evidence of prolonged lifetime of photogenerated electron / hole pairs by non-metal doping in TiO2 which helps to understand the function of non-metal dopant in photocatalysis. 5 Non-metal doping to improve the PC / PEC water splitting efficiency 5.1 Non-metal doping in TiO2: the state of the art PC / PEC water splitting processes for H2 production under solar light are prospective candidate technologies for solving energy and environment issues in the future. TiO2 is known as one of the most popular UV-light driven photocatalysts over time. Non-metal doping has been demonstrated to be an effective strategy for the band-gap engineering of TiO2 to achieve visible-light activity. Most non-metal doped TiO2 materials have been applied in the degradation of organics, which can be essential instructions for the PC / PEC water splitting. We summarize here in a comprehensive way the non-metal doped TiO2 photocatalysts for PC / PEC water splitting for H2 production from different perspectives. Numerous non-metal doped TiO2 photocatalysts have been reported to be active under visible light. The possible origins of visible light absorption and the followed photocatalysis have been discussed in details. Non-metal doping allows the formation of localized states in the band-gap of TiO2 contributing to its visible range electronic transitions. Additional states such as N 2p, C 2p, S 2p lie above the VB of TiO2 or mix with O 2p uplifting the VB. Cationic doping such as I7+, S4+, P5+ may behave as electron trap sites forming a sub band below the CB of TiO2. The defect states of oxygen vacancies and Ti3+ resulting from non-metal doping are located at above the VB and below the CB of TiO2, respectively. Various synthetic methods of non-metal doped TiO2 are also commented in detail. Most importantly, we review the creative work of recent years on non-metal doped TiO2 for enhanced PC / PEC water splitting. Nitrogen is the first attempted non-metal dopant in TiO2 and is still the most popular and adoptable one. The C, B, S and P doped TiO2 systems are developed to successively increase the efficiency of PC H2 production. The halogens have shown their great potential in the modification of the band-gap structure of TiO2 as well as in boosting the H2 generation under visible light. The processes for PC / PEC water splitting such as photon absorption, charge carriers separation and transport can be enhanced by the non-metal doping, which all contribute to the final increased PC / PEC efficiency for water splitting. Even though the PC activity of TiO2 has been remarkably improved by non-metal doping, the non-metal doped TiO2 for water splitting is still at the early stage far from the industrial application. 5.1.1 Crystalline phase and band structure of TiO2 Titanium oxide has three kinds of crystalline phases, anatase, brookite and rutile. Since the brookite TiO2 is not easy to prepare in the laboratory, the other two forms have been mostly studied in photocatalysis applications. Fig. 10 shows the crystalline structures of TiO2 in the form of TiO6 octahedrons with each Ti4+ cation surrounded by six O2– anions. Both anatase and rutile phases have tetragonal structures and the octahedron chains but in zigzag and linear forms, respectively. The anatase TiO2 has a lower density comparing to that of rutile one (3.9 versus 4.25 g/cm3) and thus could have larger specific surface area. Band-gap (E g) of the pure semiconductor refers to the energy difference between the VBM and the lowest CBM. Only if the semiconductors are excited by photons with energy (hν) equal to or higher than E g, electrons in VB can be excited to CB. More specifically, as shown in Fig. 11 , the CBM and VBM of TiO2 are consisted of “d” orbitals of titanium and “p” orbital of oxygen, which correspond respectively to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO) and highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMO) [88,289]. The band-gap is determined by the crystalline structure which results in the slight difference in the band-gap between anatase and rutile phase (3.2 vs 3.0 eV). Anatase TiO2 is considered to be more photoactive not only owing to its special structure but also to its higher fermi level around 0.1 eV than that of rutile phase [290,291]. Pristine TiO2 whatever anatase or rutile phase only responds to UV light because of its large band-gap (3.0–3.2 eV). To achieve the photoactive TiO2 under visible light, the band-gap modulation is necessary by doping other elements or other modification methods [292–295]. 5.1.2 Band-gap engineering for visible light absorption by non-metal doping The photon absorption induces the excitation of electrons from the VB to the CB of TiO2. The absorption efficiency of solar light mainly depends on the band-gap structure of TiO2. The pure TiO2 only absorbs UV light due to its large band-gap while the non-metal doping in TiO2 photocatalysts generates the visible-light absorption activity. Considerable work has proven that non-metal doping is an effective strategy for narrowing the band-gap of TiO2 for enhanced photocatalysis as summarized in Table 6 and in Fig. 12 .[438–450] There are three main mechanisms proposed to account for visible light absorption of TiO2 when using non-metal doped TiO2. Type 1: A new Valence Band (VB) is located above the Valence Band Maximum (VBM) of TiO2 resulting in the lowered excitation energy (Fig. 13 ). Electrons are generated from the doping level to the Conduction Band (CB) of TiO2 under visible light irradiation. The new uplifted VB can be originated from different kinds of impurity states. Asahi et al. and some other groups claimed that the new VB is from the mixed states of O 2p with the 2p states of dopants such as N, C and B as shown in Fig. 13(a) [47,192,327,328]. Umebayashi et al. presented the red shift in the absorption edge of S-doped TiO2 caused by mixing the S 3p states with the VB of O 2p [63]. Recently, other researchers stated isolated impurity states of non-metal above the VB of TiO2 (Fig. 13b) [329–332]. Livraghi reported that isolated states generated by single-atom nitrogen centres played an essential role in the visible light absorption and charge transport (Fig. 13c) [333]. While Ihara et al. had concluded that the visible light absorption could be originated from oxygen defect sites in the form of NO species generated by the nitrogen doping, rather than from the nitrogen states itself [334]. Thus, it is also possible that the new VB might be derived from the oxygen vacancy related defect levels. Oxygen vacancy as shown in Fig. 13(d) has already been proved to be the prevalent defect in semiconductor materials, which narrows the band-gap and promotes electron-hole separation [335]. The localized oxygen vacancy states in the lattice of TiO2 created by non-metal doping can effectively expand the visible light absorption range. However, the states of oxygen vacancy are still under debate. Some researchers suggested that this kind of states should be situated above the VB of TiO2 [329,336,337], while others advised that it should be located below the CB of TiO2 [338,339]. Type 2: A new sub band is formed below the conduction band minimum (CBM) resulting in a lowered band energy of TiO2. The photo-exited electrons from the VB will be trapped in the sub band facilitating electrons transfer under visible light (Fig. 14 ). This sub band could be consisted of Ti3+ 3d states created by non-metal doping during the vacuum calcination process as shown in Fig. 14(a) and (b) [271,340–343]. Ti3+ self-doped TiO2 known as black TiO2 has been demonstrated to be responsible for visible-light absorption, which is attributed to the introduction of new sub band below the CBM [24,344,345]. Another statement is that the sub band might be originated from cations of non-metal elements. Su et al. have reported the new states of I7+ from the IO4- group located below the CBM of TiO2 and suggested that the photoexcitation from the VB of TiO2 to the surface IO4- is responsible for the visible-light response of the I-doped TiO2 as shown in Fig. 14(c) [323]. The transition level of S4+ is also found to be below the CBM of TiO2 which induces electron emissions from O 2p to the impurity energy level (S4+) under visible light as illustrated in Fig. 14(d) [162,346]. Type 3: The visible light absorption of TiO2 can also be resulted from the interplay of type 1 and 2 [193,347,348] (Fig. 15 ). The extent of red shift to visible light region in TiO2 will be enhanced due to the synergistic effect. The most common situation for this case is co-doping with non-metal elements and the in-situ created Ti3+ in TiO2 as shown in Fig. 15(a) [193,347,348]. Electrons can be injected from the doping level to Ti3+ 3d level more easily because of the significantly narrowed band-gap. Ti3+can trap these electrons and prolong the lifetime of photo-induced electron-hole pairs and hinder their recombination as illustrated in Fig. 15(c) [340]. Besides, co-doping with different non-metal elements is used for further tuning the band structure of both VB and CB of TiO2 [349–352]. In addition to the above three types of doping effects for band-gap narrowing, some researchers proposed that visible light absorption can be originated from the existence of colour centres in the band structure of doped TiO2 rather than from the band-gap narrowing as shown in Fig. 15(b) and (d) [353–355]. The colour centre also known as F-centre (Farbe-Zentrum, from the original German Farbe-Zentrum, where Farbe means color and zentrum means centre), is a type of crystallographic defect in which an anionic vacancy, very often oxygen vacancy is filled with one or more unpaired electrons, which tend to absorb visible light. The electrons in the oxygen vacancies can also reduce the adjacent Ti4+ into Ti3+ species [356]. Due to the redox potential of non-metal elements and oxygen-deficient synthesis condition, the oxygen vacancies and Ti3+ colour centre are easily formed during the doping process resulting in visible light activity. In short, all these localized states in non-metal doped TiO2 can be responsible for the visible light activity as summarized in Fig. 16 . 5.2 Recent advances in non-metal doped TiO2 for PC / PEC water splitting Hereby, we review recent progress on non-metal doping in TiO2 in the terms of synthesis protocols, morphologies, and their effect on the PC / PEC activity for H2 production and proposed mechanisms. Fig. 17 and Table 7 summarizes the performance of non-metal doped TiO2 developed in recent years for PC / PEC water splitting. The relevant parameters including the dopant content, light sources, type, and concentration of liquid media (electrolyte or scavenger solution) are listed in the table. The noble metals such as Pt, Pd are employed as assisted co-catalysts. 5.2.1 Nitrogen doping Nitrogen doped TiO2 is one of the most promising and investigated photocatalyst system for H2 production under visible light irradiation [61,86,334,378]. In general, the substitutional N 2p impurity states are localized above the top of the O 2p valence contributing to the band-gap narrowing [379,380]. While interstitial N atoms bind to O lattice ions in the form of NO species, the resulted new energy states lie above the VB of TiO2, and thus the excitation energy is shifted towards visible region [101,333,380]. Kumar et al. reported N-doped TiO2 with a narrowed band gap (2.7 eV) and highly increased STH efficiency of 0.5% in an outdoor sunlight [430]. Kong et al. also obtained heterostructure of N doped TiO2 and carbon derived from N-doped MXene [432]. Owing to the N doping effect, the band gap of TiO2 was reduced from 3.2 eV to 3.59 eV successfully extending the absorbing light to visible light region and resulting in a outstanding H2 evolution rate of 102.6 μmol h−1g−1 under solar light. Due to the large number of research works in literatures, and the length limit of this review, it is not possible to discuss all these results. Some of key findings of N-TiO2 for H2 production are presented in the following section. N doped Double-Wall TiO2 NanoTubes (N-DW-TiO2 NTs) were prepared by a facile two steps anodization method using the NH4F both for etching and in situ N doping source. As shown in Fig. 18 (a-d), compared to conventional N doped Single-Wall TiO2 NanoTubes (N-SW-TiO2 NTs) [297], the surface area, smoothness and orderliness of the N doped Double-Wall TiO2 NanoTubes (N-DW-TiO2 NTs were improved [381–383]. As shown in Fig. 18(e,f), photocurrent density on the N-DW-TiO2 NTs is higher throughout the potential window and reaches to a high value of 1.51 mA/cm2 at 1.23 V vs RHE, 136% higher than that on N-SW-TiO2 NTs. The N-DW-TiO2 NTs show a maximum photon-to-H2 efficiency of 1.26% at 0.5 V vs RHE which is 2.7 times that of N-SW-TiO2 NTs (Fig. 18g). The maximum IPCE value of N-DW-TiO2 NTs is 56% at 390 nm, which is three times as that of N-SW-TiO2 NTs (Fig. 18h). The PC efficiency is highly improved by the double wall structure of TiO2. In other words, the nitrogen doping in N-DW-TiO2 NTs can be more effective than N-SW-TiO2 NTs for PEC water splitting [297]. Bio-inspired fabrication of nitrogen doped TiO2 by using a living mussel (Cristaria Plicata) as cradle has first been reported by Xie et al. As presented in Fig. 18(i-l), the tablets consisted with amorphous TiO2 precursor with a diameter of 10 mm and thickness of 1–2 mm was implanted into the mussel’s body as a pearl nucleus. After 15 ~ 90 days of mineralization, the TiO2 tablets were wrapped with thin layers of nacre. The nitrogen doped TiO2 photocatalyst (denoted as bm-TiO2) in the shape of nanospherical clusters was obtained after washing and heat treatments. The H2 production rate of pristine TiO2 is almost zero under visible light, whereas the H2 production rate of the bm-TiO2 increases up to 55 µmol h-1g−1 as shown in Fig. 18(m). The visible-light efficiency of TiO2 is improved by the nitrogen doping with the special assistance from Cristaria Plicata. The interstitial nitrogen doping in TiO2 is confirmed by the XPS (inset: Fig. 18n). The N concentration is calculated to be 0.44 at% based on the XPS result. The valence-band XPS spectra of TiO2 samples are shown in Fig. 18(o) (inset), compared with pristine TiO2, the main absorption onset in the VB of bm-TiO2 is located at 1.0 eV and the band tail blue-shifts towards the vacuum level approximately 0.6 eV. The band gap shift is attributed to the presence of the lattice defects which further confirms the interstitial nitrogen doping in TiO2. Nitrogen doping in TiO2 by mimicking natural pearl process in a living mussel is very innovative but still in its early stage, this approach extends the chemical methodologies for fabrication functional N-doped oxide materials. Another creative idea is to incorporate dopants into TiO2 with distinctively dominant facets. Most anatase TiO2 crystals are dominated by the thermodynamically stable {101} facets while the TiO2 with dominant {001} facets are more reactive [384,385]. The nitrogen doped TiO2 with dominant {001} facet was first fabricated by the hydrothermal treatment of titanium nitride (TiN) in hydrofluoric acid (HF) [296]. The H2 evolution rates, measured from photochemical reduction of water with methanol as a scavenger, of N-TiO2 are 1483 and 81 μmol·h−1·m−2 under 220–770 nm and 420–770 nm, respectively. While the H2 evolution rates of pure TiO2 ({001} dominant facet) and N-TiO2 (without preferential {001} facets) are 1333 and 38 μmol·h−1·m−2 under 220–770 nm, respectively. No obvious H2 production is detected in the presence of TiO2 ({001} dominant facet) and N-TiO2 (without preferential {001} facets) under visible light [296]. It can be concluded that nitrogen doped anatase TiO2 sheets with dominant {001} facets have superior activity for H2 production especially under visible light. This work can also be extended to other nonmetal doped anatase TiO2 sheets with dominant {001} facets. The surface heterojunction composed of both {001} and {101} facets has also been considered to enhance the photoefficiency of TiO2. The N-doped TiO2 nanobelts with a coexposed (101) and (001) facets were hydrothermally synthesized [366]. As shown in Fig. 19 (a), compared to the pure TiO2, the N-doped TiO2 samples exhibit stronger absorption indicating enhanced visible-light activity due to the nitrogen doping. The H2 evolution rate increases as the nitrogen doping content under visible light (400 nm < λ < 800 nm). As shown in Fig. 19(b), the H2 production rate of TiO2 nanobelts with 2.08 at% N is 670 μmol h−1 g−1, being much higher than the values of other N-doped TiO2 nanobelts with a single facet exposed [361,386]. The surface heterojunction in TiO2 not only promotes the water molecule decomposition but also improves the ability of the charge separation. In addition, the result of cycling tests on the 2.08-N-TiO2 (Fig. 19c) shows no obvious decrease for H2 production displaying a satisfactory stability. The TiO2 nanobelts show higher photocurrent response with an increasing N content. Due to the existence of surface heterojunction, the electrons in (001) are attracted immediately to (101) and transferred to the active reaction sites to combine with H+ to release H2. Conversely, the holes are attracted immediately from (101) to (001) which has a better capability of promoting these holes to react with OH− to form hydroxyl radicals (OH•). The N-doped TiO2 nanobelts with coexposed two dominant surfaces of (101) and (001) facets exhibit significantly enhanced PC activities. 5.2.2 Boron doping Boron with a small ionic radius can be substitutionally incorporated at oxygen sites more easily which gives rise to mid gap states. On the other hand, the interstitial boron existing in the form of B σ + (σ ≤ 3) behaves as the electron donor. The enhanced charge transfer could be attributed to the synergistic action of both doping types. The active Ti3+ species can also be induced by the boron doping resulting in self-doped TiO2 (TiO2- x ). A series of B-TiO2- x photocatalysts were prepared via sol–gel synthesis method using boric acid as boron source [201]. As shown in Fig. 20 , with increasing dopant concentration, the intensity of peak at 191.8 eV ascribed to interstitial B becomes stronger. The two major peaks of Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 are shifted to the lower binding energy indicating the formation of Ti3+ species [387,388]. The EPR signal of Ti3+ at a g-value of 1.98729 gradually increases with increased doping amount of B from 2% to 10%. The concentration of Ti3+ species is estimated to be ca. 30 μmol/g in the 10% B-TiO2- x sample. The H2 evolution rate generally increases with increasing the content of dopant B. Particularly, the B-TiO2- x with 10 wt% B has the highest rate of 11.8 mmol h-1g−1 which is 3.5 times that of the commercial P25. In addition, no obvious drop of H2 production rate was observed after 42 h PC reaction including 21 cycling tests showing the good stability of B-TiO2- x . It has been concluded that the interstitial B doping not only leads to the formation of abundant and stable Ti3+ species but also favours the lattice disorder of B-TiO2- x photocatalysts. Therefore, two groups of mid-gap states are formed, which result in a significant reduction of the band-gap. The band-gap engineering can promote the photogenerated electron mobility and provide the B-O-Ti3+ structure as trapping sites to prevent electron-pairs from recombination, which ultimately enhances the solar-light PC activity of B-TiO2- x toward H2 production water splitting. Furthermore, the location of heteroatoms in TiO2 is supposed to influence the PC reaction preferences towards electron reduction or hole oxidation. By controlling the spatial distribution of boron from the core to the shell within a microsphere, the effect of the heteroatoms on modulating H2 and oxygen evolution was revealed. The Fig. 20(d) illustrates the boron distribution-dependent electronic structures, the core part has the intrinsic band-gap which is independent on the chemical states of boron. While the VBM of the shell containing interstitial boron is inclined to shift downwards due to the band bending effect originating from the existence of B σ + and Ti3+. Thus, the holes from the lowered VB of TiO2 in the shell have a stronger oxidative power than those from the VB of TiO2 in the core. The TiO2 with boron in the core shows a 4-fold improvement in H2 evolution compared to the TiO2 with boron in the shell. Furthermore, the boron-containing shell leads to a 4.5-fold improvement in oxygen evolution compared to the shell with a boron gradient. The PC reaction preference is thus switched to the oxygen producing reactions by doping boron in the shell. The microsphere of TiO2 with boron in the shell shows the typical electron conduction behaviour of TiO2. Whereas with concentrated boron in the core, a cooperative conduction of electron and B σ + ions is observed but only at the first scan indicating the high diffusion capability of boron derived by the electric field. This work clearly advances the designing and constructing of efficient photocatalysts by spatial heteroatom engineering. 5.2.3 Sulphur doping The sulphur doped TiO2 has also been studied for visible-light photocatalysis. Because S has a similar electron structure with O but with a larger ionic radius, introducing sulphur into TiO2 lattice could significantly modify the electronic structures of TiO2 [159,180,389,390]. The sulphur has different oxidation states such as S2+, S4+ or S6+ in TiO2 playing a multi-type doping effect on PC reactions. The in-situ S-doped TiO2 nanopillars were synthesized by a facile one step thermal treatment of titanyl sulphate hydrated heating up to 500, 600, 700, and 800 °C denoted as T500, T600, T700 and T800, respectively [53]. The pure anatase TiO2 transforms into rutile at 600 °C while the S-doped TiO2 maintains its anatase phase at 700 °C resulting in the higher crystallinity and less surface defects of anatase TiO2. The morphology of TiO2 nanopillars with diameter of around 3 µm can be clearly observed by the SEM and TEM presented in Fig. 21 (a,b). With increasing calcination temperature, the doping content of S element gradually decreases as revealed by the XPS spectra (Fig. 21c). The T700 sample calcined at phase transition temperature shows the highest PC H2 evolution rate of 163.9 µmol h-1g−1 (Fig. 21d). The introduction of S in TiO2 highly promotes the PC performance, which is attributed to the high anatase crystallinity and improvement of photon utilization. Modification of rutile TiO2 by doping for water splitting is investigated due to its chemical inertness which is, however, a desired merit to achieve photostability. The unique S-doped rutile TiO2 with core–shell structure was obtained by reduction of TiO2 with molten Al and the following sulfidation in the H2S gas [66], as shown in Fig. 22 (a). As H2S reduces the phase transition energy from anatase to rutile, the anatase TiO2 can completely transform into the rutile allotrope at a relatively low temperature like 600 °C. Meanwhile, these S2− anions occupy the oxygen vacancies and introduce new electronic transitions from the S 3p orbitals to the Ti 3d orbitals during the sulphuration process. The band-gap can be further narrowed with the formation of by-product of Ti3+. The S-doped rutile TiO2 (R′-TiO2-S) shows nearly 30-folds improvement over pristine rutile TiO2 in PC water-splitting activity (Fig. 22b). The PEC measurement of R′-TiO2-S photoelectrode shows a high STH efficiency of 1.67% (Fig. 22c). The R′-TiO2-S also impressively enhances the IPCE value in both UV region (300–380 nm) and visible region (400–580 nm) (Fig. 22d). The upward shift of Fermi level in the shell of S-doped TiO2 is supposed to bend the band edge of TiO2 and to facilitate the charge separation at the interface of S-doped shell part and the electrolyte. In conclusion, the S and Ti3+ doping level extend the light absorption to the visible and even to near-infrared region, which result in the significantly improved PC / PEC activity. The formation of defect states in non-metal doped TiO2 is inevitable during the synthesizing process. Defects like oxygen vacancies and Ti interstitial can act as active sites to boost PC reaction as mentioned above. But these dopant-induced defects also have a negative effect on PC activity due to the charge carrier trapping and recombination sites. A good compromise between these two aspects is crucial for the optimization of the photoactivity [61,391–393]. The laminated defect-controlled S-doped TiO2 on carbon substrate (LDC-S-TiO2/C) was synthesized involving a S impregnation of Ti3C2MXenes followed by two-step oxidation processes. After the second oxidation, the excess carbon is reduced while the defects concentration is increased as shown in Fig. 23 (a). The undoped laminated TiO2 (L-TiO2/C) is taken as a reference sample. The charge-transfer efficiency under visible light can be estimated by the measurement of transient photocurrent density (TPC) under visible light as shown in Fig. 23(b). Apparently, LDC-S-TiO2/C with further oxidation achieves the highest photoinduced current density, about two times that of L-S-TiO2/C (0.135 mA cm−2 vs 0.062 mA cm−2). The sulphur doping might be responsible for the reduced Gibbs free energy ΔG of water splitting, accelerating the carrier-transfer step and H2 release. As shown in Fig. 23(c), the LDC-S-TiO2/C shows 17-fold and 48-fold improvements on H2 generation rates under full-spectrum light and visible light comparing to undoped TiO2. In addition, the porous carbon substrate can work as the cocatalyst and provide more active sites. This novel strategy shed a new insight for designing effective S-doped TiO2 for solar energy conversion. 5.2.4 Phosphorus doping In the case of phosphorus doping, two kinds of possible states including cationic (P5+) and anionic (P3-) exist in TiO2. The P5+ state originates from the substitution on the Ti4+site accompanied with an electron liberation and the increased electrical conductivity. Since the ionic radius of P5+ is smaller than that of Ti4+, the P incorporation into TiO2 lattice with a Ti-O-P bond is more feasible. The hybridization of Ti 2p and P 2p orbits can narrow the band-gap of TiO2 by forming new donor states below the CB of TiO2. On the contrary, the substitution on the O2– site leads to the formation of P3- state and the simultaneous neutralization of an electron in the system. The presence of P3- state decreases the charge carrier density and may promote the electron-hole recombination. Besides, the commonly applied impurity sources contain phosphorous with positive valence such as phosphoric acid or phosphate. It is difficult to restore P species from oxidation states to P3- even under the reducing atmosphere. Thus, the enhanced PC activity is mostly driven by the dominant P5+ in TiO2 [185,394,395]. The P cation-doped TiO2 for PEC water splitting was first reported by Li et al. The hierarchical TiO2 nanotube photonic crystals (TiO2 NTPC) were prepared by two-step electrochemical anodization. The P was then loaded into TiO2 NTPC (P- TiO2 NTPC) by CVD process using NaH2PO2 as the phosphorus source. Fig. 24 (a) shows the hierarchically periodical nanoring structure of P-TiO2 NTPC with an average diameter of 150 nm [254]. A computer-simulated finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) procedure was conducted (Fig. 24a right part). The top layer of photonic nanoring shows strong electric field intensity, indicating the light harvesting in these nanorings. The optical absorption was significantly enhanced in the region of 400–500 nm. The red shift of the band-gap to 2.90 eV (Fig. 24b) can be attributed to the formation of new donor states below the CB of TiO2. The PEC performance of P-TiO2 NTPC is superior and the photocurrent density value for P-TiO2 NTPC presents a 140% increase compared to that of undoped TiO2 under solar light. The photoconversion efficiency is improved by the P doping in TiO2 under both UV and visible light. Apparently, the combination of P cation doping with the unique photonic nanostructures of TiO2 NTPCs effectively heighten the PEC property under solar light. The dual-doping of P5+ and P3- in TiO2 has also been reported by employing PH3 treatment at a low temperature (300 °C) for improving the PEC performance of TiO2 nanorods. Consequently, three doping species which are Ti3+, P5+, and P3- are observed. Incorporation with these ions in TiO2 leads to the enhanced optical absorption with the colour change from white to yellow as presented in Fig. 24(c). On the other hand, the PH3 treatment increases the density of various surface states, especially like the P3- states which facilitate the charge recombination. However, compensated with the positive effect of P5+ and Ti3+, PH3 treated TiO2 still has large carrier density resulting in faster transport and longer lifetime of photogenerated electrons. The photocurrent of photoelectrode based on PH3 treated TiO2 is 5 times higher than that of pristine one (1.8 mA/cm2 vs 0.35 mA/cm2) under solar light as shown in Fig. 24(d) [396]. This facile PH3 annealing strategy for P doping is effective for improving the photoactivity of TiO2 and allows the further optimization on other semiconductor materials. 5.2.5 Halogen doping In recent years, the doping by halogen elements (F, Cl, Br, I) has triggered a new area of research on TiO2 materials. The halogen doped TiO2 materials exhibit an enhanced PC activity under both UV and visible light. The ionic radius of halogen and oxygen increases in the order F < O < Cl < Br < I (i. e., 1.19, 1.4, 1.81, 1.96, and 2.20 Å, respectively, at a six-coordinate site) [397]. In terms of ionic size, F atoms are in favour of substitution at O sites, which promote the formation of oxygen vacancies like F and F- centres and lower the CB edge of TiO2. While I atoms prefer to occupy Ti sites existing as oxidation states like I5+ / I7+ [58,126,168,398]. These halogen atoms highly improve the photogenerated electron mobility and inhibit the rapid recombination of electron-hole pairs. Both F and I doped TiO2 electrodes show enhanced photoelectric conversion efficiency for dye sensitized solar cells under simulated sunlight [399–403]. Specially, it is well known that all the halogens form acids when bonded to H. The surface acidification by halogens doping increases the adsorption of reactant polar molecules that boosts PC reactions on the catalyst surface [326,404]. Zhang et al. prepared the fluorine-doped TiO2 using anhydrous hydrogen fluoride (AHF) via vapor-phase fluorination at low temperature [376]. Due to the presence of the electronegative fluorine atoms, F-TiO2 has more active sites on the surface. Thus, the adsorption of hydroxyl radicals on the TiO2 is remarkably increased by the surface fluorination, being highly favourable for PC properties. The more the surface OH radicals, the higher the photooxidation ability of the sample. The F-TiO2 reveals highly enhanced PC H2 evolution rate of 113.1 µmol/h, being two times higher than that of pure TiO2 (51.2 µmol/h) under UV light irradiation [377]. The F- can be selectively inserted in {001} facets of anatase TiO2 using HF etching of TiO2 nanosheets with co-exposed {001} and {101} facets [59]. Since the photoinduced holes are transferred to {001} facets, the Ti3+ states and oxygen vacancies introduced in {001} facets by F- doping significantly accelerate the transportation of holes and reduce the recombination of electron/hole pairs as illustrated in Fig. 25 (a). Consequently, the H2 production rate of the as-prepared sample under the visible-light illumination is remarkably increased to 18.27 mmol g-1h−1 and the quantum efficiency is up to 21.6% at λ = 420 nm (Fig. 25b-e). Apparently, F- doping of {001} facets of TiO2 is an effective strategy for improving the spatial separation of photogenerated carriers as well as the PC water splitting. Other halogens (Cl, Br, I) modified TiO2 catalysts were mostly used in the degradation of organics. The mono-doped TiO2 with other halogens (Cl, Br, I) for enhanced PC / PEC water splitting has not been reported. Co-doping halogens of Cl- and Br- in TiO2 was conducted by hydrothermal synthesis [326]. Such co-doping will be discussed in the following sections. 5.2.6 Carbon doping Carbon, as a common non-metallic material, has a large electron-storage capacity, superior charge-transfer, and good permeability into TiO2. Various theoretical and experimental works have focused on the study of the visible light absorption properties of carbon doped TiO2 [62,405]. Carbon doping widens the region of absorption light and sensitizes white TiO2 by affecting the electronic environments of Ti cations and O anions. As dopants and sensitizer, carbon significantly improves the PC activity of TiO2 in the visible-light region [149,303,306,406–409]. For instance, the C-modified TiO2 samples were obtained from the pyrolysis of hydrothermally synthesized TiO2-sucrose composites [65]. The C-TiO2 exhibited high PC activity for the H2 evolution (625 mL g-1h−1) under simulated solar light irradiation. The PL intensity of C doped TiO2 is significantly faded compared to that of pure TiO2, which implies the suppressed recombination of photogenerated electron-holes. The carbon modification may cause the formation of oxygen vacancies that trap electrons and facilitate efficient electron-hole separation. Due to the doping or surface modification effect of carbon in TiO2, the H2 production from PC / PEC water splitting is highly enhanced. For example, photoanode of carbon doped TiO2 nanowire arrays exhibited a ～ 70% enhancement of photocurrent density comparing to that of photoanode based on the pristine TiO2 [410]. A new strategy for preparing highly carbon-doped TiO2 (HC-TiO2) at low temperature has been developed by employing Ti3C2 MXene as the precursor [370]. As shown in Fig. 26 (a,b), the multangular flower-like morphology composes of tightly aggregated nanorods with a diameter dimension of 35 ± 10 nm. The small size of these nanorods is beneficial to the carrier diffusion during the PC reaction. The HC-TiO2 with a high carbon content (20 wt%) red-shifts the absorption edges of TiO2. The impurity levels above the VBM promote the transfer rate of photogenerated electrons. The HC-TiO2 electrode shows remarkably higher photocurrent which is 8 times that of P25 (Fig. 26c) and exhibits higher H2 evolution rate of 33.04 µmol h-1g−1 which is around 10 times higher than that of P25 (Fig. 26d). This work enriched the synthesis method of C-doped TiO2 from 2D MXene based materials for realizing highly efficient PC H2 production. Recently, the carbon-doped TiO2 derived from Ti3C2 MXene composed with g-C3N4 achieved PC H2 production rate as high as 1409 μmol/h/g which is about 8 times and 24 times higher than the activity of pure g-C3N4 and C-TiO2 [435]. Novel core–shell structure has also been reported, which has large specific surface area and facilitates the light absorption. The core–shell structured TiO2 with functional components shows intensively enhanced PC activity [411–413]. The carbon doped TiO2 with core–shell structure was also synthesized by oxidizing TiC in air at 350 °C for 30, 60, 90, 120, and 180 min, denoted as TC1-TC5 respectively [370], as shown in Fig. 26(e). All the TiC@C-TiO2 samples possess higher PC activity for water splitting than P25 under visible light irradiation as shown in Fig. 26(l,m). The photoelectron transmission and the followed catalytic reactions in the core–shell structured C-doped TiO2 are affected by the annealing conditions. In general, heating treatments under various temperatures for different durations influence the specific surface area and the thickness of core and shell parts as well as the dopant concentration in TiC@C-TiO2. The good photostability of TC2 is shown (demonstrated) by cycling PC tests under 6 h of visible illumination (Fig. 26n). Moreover, the TiC@C-TiO2 core–shell samples show almost the same H2 evolution with or without Pt cocatalyst presented in Fig. 26(o). Therefore, the TiC not only provides the carbon dopant source, but also acts as a good support for TiO2 photocatalyst. The carbon impurity effectively narrows the band-gap of TiO2 and enhances the light absorption. The photoelectron transfer is also fastened in the presence of the TiC phase and the recombination rate of charge carriers is thus inhibited. Due to the synergetic effect of the carbon dopant and the inner TiC, PC property of TiO2 for water splitting is highly improved. Furthermore, in order to produce high levels of H2, the heterojunctions of C-doped TiO2 with other visible light sensitive catalysts were also investigated. Yun et al. deposited the Au@CdS core–shell structure on 0.04 at% C doped TiO2 (TiO1.96C0.04) with the help of UV light irradiation. This combination denoted as CdS/Au/TiO1.96C0.04 gives rise to the reduction potential of protons and the ability of charge separation due to the Z-scheme mechanism. The novel system of CdS/Au/TiO1.96C0.04 produces a H2 amount approximately 4 times higher than CdS/Au/TiO2 without the carbon doping under visible light irradiation. The heterostructure of C-doped TiO2 with g-C3N4 was also reported with improved light absorption and lower charge recombination rate which are beneficial to PC reactions [370]. The photocatalysts of C-TiO2/g-C3N4 exhibit superior visible light activity with the highest H2 generation rate of 1.15 mmol h-1g−1. The apparent quantum efficiency of C-TiO2/g-C3N4 photocatalysts is significantly increased to 6.2% under 420 nm irradiation, compared to 2.6% of the pristine g-C3N4. The carbon coating in TiO2 often occurs during the carbon doping process. Both carbon doping and coating can improve the photoactivity of TiO2 due to the band-gap narrowing originated from carbon doping and the improved charges separation by carbon coating, respectively. The enhanced PC / PEC activity might be attributed to synergistic effect of both carbon doping and coating in TiO2. Wang et al. reported both carbon doped and coated TiO2 as photocatalysts boosting 8 and 11 times higher photocurrent than that carbon coated TiO2 and carbon doped TiO2. Only carbon coating cannot promote the PC activity under visible light while the only carbon doping cannot help to prevent the rapid recombination of photogenerated electron / hole pairs [420]. Thus, the dual effect of carbon doping and coating taken into account when considering the research work of carbon doping in TiO2. 5.2.7 Co-doping by two elements 5.2.7.1 Co-doping by N and B Since both nitrogen and boron dopants can promote the PC activity, the N and B codoped TiO2 could benefit a has synergistic effect in which the N atoms improve the absorption efficiency of visible light and the B atoms inhibit the TiO2 crystallite growth and boost the charge separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs [414–416]. Furthermore, in addition to the (NiO)̇ species (i = interstitial), the N-B co-doped TiO2 has been further demonstrated to contain extrinsic defects of (NOB)̇ species, which commonly exist in the N-doped TiO2. The (NOB)̇ species are supposed to be based on the bonding of both interstitial N and B atoms to the same lattice oxygen ion. The (NOB)̇ can easily trap one electron leading to the (NOB)− diamagnetic centre which lies at approximately 0.4 eV above the VB of TiO2 contributing to the visible light activity [417]. Liu et al. reported a red anatase TiO2 with B and N co-doping for full spectrum solar energy conversion. The pre-doped interstitial boron weakens the surrounding Ti-O bonds and thus improve the solubility of nitrogen in TiO2 resulting in significantly narrowed band-gap of TiO2 down to 1.94 eV. This red TiO2 based photoanode shows a good PEC activity for water splitting under visible light [418]. The sol–gel method synthesized B and N codoped TiO2 with Pd as the cocatalyst shows a high H2 production rate of 500 µmol h-1g−1 [372]. 5.2.7.2 Co-doping by two halogen elements Br- and Cl- co-doped nanocrystalline TiO2 was conducted by a hydrothermal synthesis [326]. By increasing the acidity through addition of HBr, TiO2 with anatase, mixed anatase/rutile, rutile, mixed rutile/brookite, mixed anatase/rutile/brookite, and rutile phases are obtained. The TiO2 is transformed into rutile phase as the doping amount of Br increases. Br- and Cl- co-doping causes the absorption edge of TiO2 to shift to a lower energy region.
